user_query: Could you clarify the role of UNDP in promoting solar energy solutions in urban areas of Thailand?
answer:
UNDP plays a crucial role in promoting solar energy solutions in urban areas of Thailand. The organization works closely with the Thai government, local communities, and other stakeholders to implement sustainable energy projects and initiatives. UNDP's efforts focus on several key areas:

  1. Promoting renewable energy: UNDP supports the development and implementation of solar energy projects in urban areas of Thailand. These projects involve installing solar panels on rooftops, public buildings, and other suitable locations to generate clean and renewable electricity.
  2. Capacity building: UNDP provides training and capacity-building programs to local communities, technicians, and policymakers to enhance their knowledge and skills in solar energy technologies. This helps create a skilled workforce that can support the installation, maintenance, and management of solar power systems.
  3. Policy advocacy: UNDP collaborates with the Thai government to develop favorable policies and regulations that promote the adoption of solar energy solutions. This includes advocating for feed-in tariffs, net metering schemes, tax incentives, and other measures that encourage investment in solar power.
  4. Social inclusion: UNDP ensures that its solar energy projects prioritize social inclusion by targeting marginalized communities within urban areas. By providing access to affordable and clean energy, these projects help improve livelihoods, reduce poverty, and enhance overall well-being.

The work of UNDP in promoting solar energy solutions aligns with global sustainability goals such as Sustainable Development Goal 7 (SDG 7), which aims to ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, and modern energy for all. By supporting the transition towards renewable sources like solar power in urban areas of Thailand, UNDP contributes to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, combating climate change impacts.

(Source: UNDP Thailand - Promoting Solar Energy)

doc-12.summary:
The article discusses the concept of the Just Transition and its relevance to Africa. It highlights the challenges and complexities of implementing just transition initiatives in Africa, including the high rates of unemployment, informal labor, and external forces that perpetuate inequality. The article also explores different streams of the Just Transition movement, such as the Just Energy Transition, Just Rural Transition, Just Urban Transition, and Just Circular Economy Transition. It provides examples of initiatives in each stream and emphasizes the need for community-driven visions and definitions. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of consensus-building at the local and national level and the need for more climate financing dedicated to African-led initiatives.

Farmers in Africa, particularly smallholder farmers, face challenges due to volatile commodity prices and lack of bargaining power. Initiatives like the Living Income Differential (LID) in the cocoa industry have not been effective in protecting farmers' incomes. Climate-induced declines in crop production further exacerbate the situation. The Africa Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCFTA) may expose smallholder farmers to increased competition without access to markets or value-addition opportunities. Just Transition initiatives in Africa need to consider the interlinkages between rural and urban areas, as well as the potential for clean energy technologies in agriculture. However, there are challenges in implementing Just Transition in Africa, including funding constraints, administrative issues, and the need for consensus-building at the local and national levels. The African context requires specific programmatic and political considerations, including the inclusion of marginalized voices and the avoidance of reinforcing inequalities.

doc-29.title: Tracking SDG7 | The Energy Progress Report 2022
doc-29.extract: THE ENERGY PROGRESS REPORT 2022 TRACKING SDG7 joint report of the custodian agencies United Nations Statistics Division © 2022 International Bank for Reconstruction and Development / The World Bank 1818 Street NW Washington DC 20433 Telephone: 1000 Internet: This work is joint product of the staf of the ﬁve custodian agencies, namely the World Bank, the International Energy Agency, the International Renewable Energy Agency, the United Nations, and the World Health Organization, with external contributions The ﬁndings, interpretations, and conclusions expressed in this work do not necessarily reﬂect the views of the custodian agencies, their respective Board of Executive Directors (or equivalent), members or the governments they represent The collaborating organizations do not guarantee the accuracy, completeness, or currency of the data included in this work and does not assume responsibility for any errors, omissions, or discrepancies in the information, or liability with respect to the use of or failure to use the information, methods, processes, or conclusions set forth
doc-29.summary:
The Energy Progress Report 2022, jointly produced by the United Nations Statistics Division, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development / The World Bank, and other custodian agencies, assesses global progress towards achieving universal access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, and modern energy. The report highlights that while there has been some progress, particularly in access to electricity, the world is still not on track to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal 7 targets by 2030. The report emphasizes the need for increased efforts and investments to accelerate progress, especially in the most vulnerable countries. It also calls for greater support from international actors to expand access to clean energy and improve energy efficiency. The report provides updated data and indicators to track progress across different energy targets and highlights the importance of reliable and high-quality data for informed policymaking.

The global access to electricity has increased from 83% in 2010 to 91% in 2020, but the pace of progress has slowed in recent years. To achieve universal electricity access by 2030, the annual growth rate in global electrification needs to increase. Sub-Saharan Africa has the highest access deficit, with 77% of the global population without access to electricity. Rural areas have larger access deficits than urban areas, but rural electrification has been faster than urban electrification over the past decade. The top 20 countries with the largest access deficits are mostly in Sub-Saharan Africa. Decentralized renewable energy solutions have tripled since 2010, reaching 39 million people in 2019. Affordability of electricity remains a challenge, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa and developing countries in Asia. Tailored end-user financing is needed to expand and maintain household electricity connections.

The global population with access to electricity increased from 83% in 2010 to 91% in 2020. However, 733 million people still lack access to electricity. The main challenges in achieving universal access are bringing service to vulnerable and poor populations. Between 2010 and 2020, 1 billion people gained access to electricity, with the fastest progress in Latin America and the Caribbean. Sub-Saharan Africa has the largest proportion of the unelectrified population. The urban access rate is 97%, while the rural access rate is 83%. Decentralized renewable energy solutions, such as solar home systems and mini-grids, have provided access to electricity for 39 million people. The top 20 access-deficit countries, mostly in Sub-Saharan Africa, account for 76% of the global population without access to electricity. Kenya and Uganda have made the greatest progress in increasing access, while Nigeria and the Democratic Republic of Congo have seen slower progress. The least-electrified countries are all in Sub-Saharan Africa, with South Sudan having the lowest access rate. Rwanda and Uganda have made significant progress in increasing access.

In 2020, 69% of the global population had access to clean cooking fuels and technologies, an increase of almost 70 million people compared to previous years. However, about a third of the global population still lacked access to clean cooking. Access to clean cooking fuels and technologies increased by only 12 percentage points over the past decade. In Sub-Saharan Africa, the number of people without access is increasing at an accelerating rate. Achieving universal access to clean cooking is impossible without addressing the growing access deficit in this region. Central Asia and Southern Asia saw the most progress in increasing access to clean cooking, while Latin America and the Caribbean remained stagnant. By 2030, access to clean cooking is projected to reach 80-90% in Central Asia, Southern Asia, Eastern Asia, and South-eastern Asia.

Access to clean cooking fuels and technologies remains low in Sub-Saharan Africa and Oceania, with only about one in five people in Sub-Saharan Africa having access. The urban-rural divide in access is significant, with 86% of people in urban areas having access compared to only 48% in rural areas. The 20 countries with the largest access deficits account for more than 80% of the global population without access, and little progress has been made in most of these countries. The use of gaseous fuels for cooking has increased globally, overtaking biomass as the dominant cooking fuel. The use of electricity for cooking has also increased, particularly in urban areas. However, the use of kerosene remains notable in urban areas of low- and middle-income countries in Oceania and Sub-Saharan Africa. Closing the access gap in Sub-Saharan Africa requires increased public and private finance, as current investment falls far short of what is needed. Accelerating access to clean cooking is critical for reducing vulnerability to the COVID-19 pandemic and reducing gender inequity. The negative impacts of the lack of access to clean cooking, including health, gender, and climate impacts, are estimated to cost trillions of dollars annually. Policy interventions are needed to prioritize clean cooking, tackle cost and finance barriers, bolster sustainability and supply chains, and create awareness about impacts and solutions.

Ecuador is shifting subsidies away from LPG to renewable electricity. Nepal is promoting the use of electricity for cooking to reduce reliance on LPG imports. Achieving universal access to clean cooking would cost $1 trillion over 10 years. Strategic policies and incentives are needed to accelerate progress in clean cooking access, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa. Tools and resources are available to help countries design clean cooking programs. Efforts are being made to transition refugee camps to clean cooking fuels. The share of renewable energy in global energy consumption increased slightly in 2019. Renewable electricity has the largest share among the end-use categories. Sub-Saharan Africa has the largest share of renewable energy, but traditional biomass is still widely used. Latin America and the Caribbean have the highest share of modern renewables. The share of renewables in energy consumption varies widely among countries. Brazil and Canada have the highest shares of modern renewables among the top 20 energy consuming countries.

Renewable energy consumption in transport grew in 2019, with biofuels and renewable electricity being the main sources. However, the share of renewables in total energy consumed for transport only increased slightly. The United States, Brazil, and Europe accounted for the majority of renewable energy used in transport, with biofuels being the dominant source. China and India also saw significant growth in renewable energy consumption for transport, primarily driven by renewable electricity. To further increase the share of renewables in transport, a combination of policies supporting biofuels, nonbiogenic renewable fuels, transport electrification, renewable electricity generation, and active mobility is needed.

Global energy intensity has improved since 1990, with a 16% decrease between 2010 and 2019. However, the rate of improvement has slowed in recent years, and it is below the target set under the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Eastern Asia and Southeastern Asia achieved the highest improvement in energy intensity, while Latin America and the Caribbean had the lowest improvement. Among the top 20 energy-consuming countries, China has the fastest rate of improvement in energy intensity, followed by the United Kingdom. The freight transport sector experienced the highest improvement in energy intensity, while the residential buildings sector had the lowest improvement. The rising share of renewables in electricity generation has contributed to improved energy intensity. Digitalization is seen as a key factor in accelerating progress towards SDG and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

Energy efficiency measures can have the greatest impact and benefit by focusing on areas such as building management systems, smart home technologies, and digitalization. These measures can significantly reduce energy consumption in buildings and households. Digitalization also offers system-wide benefits, including increased reliability, operational efficiency, and cost reductions. It can also support economic and social development, such as bringing clean energy solutions to marginalized communities. Additionally, energy efficiency policies should be strengthened and investment in energy efficiency measures should be scaled up to meet the targets of sustainable development goals.

The text discusses various measures of energy intensity, including the ratio between industry total final energy consumption (TFEC) and industry value-added, the ratio between total energy supply (TES) and gross domestic product (GDP), and the energy intensity of different sectors such as services, agriculture, passenger transport, and freight transport. It also mentions the efficiency of fossil fuel electricity generation and power transmission and distribution losses. Data sources include the International Energy Agency (IEA) and the World Development Indicators (WDI) database.

The text discusses various energy intensity ratios, including those related to electricity losses, electricity output, agriculture, passenger transport, freight transport, residential energy consumption, and fossil fuel electricity generation efficiency. The data sources for these ratios are mentioned as IEA Energy Balances and WDI.

International public financial flows to support clean energy in developing countries declined by 23% in 2019 compared to 2018. The total amount of funding, $14 billion, was less than half of the peak in 2017. Hydropower received the largest share of commitments at 26%, followed by solar energy at 21% and wind energy at 12%. The majority of commitments were directed to 22 countries, with Nigeria, Guinea, and India receiving the most funding. Least-developed countries received 7% of commitments, but the amount decreased from the previous year. The mix of financial instruments supporting clean energy is changing, with a decrease in debt instruments and an increase in grants. Overall, international public financial flows for clean energy remain far below what is needed to achieve SDG 7.

International public financial flows to developing countries for clean energy have been misclassified in some cases, leading to inaccurate reporting. Solar rooftop programs, for example, have been classified as solar energy commitments in the OECD's Creditor Reporting System. It is important to ensure that investments are accurately classified under the right technologies. Over the past decade, commitments to clean energy in developing countries have increased significantly, reaching almost triple the value in 2019 compared to 2010. However, there was a decrease in the five-year moving average of international public financial flows in 2019, indicating a slowdown in international public flows. The impacts of COVID-19 are likely to further depress international public flows in the future. The distribution of flows by technology shows that hydropower attracted the largest share of commitments, followed by solar energy and wind energy. Non-renewable energy still received a significant amount of public financial flows, highlighting the need for donors to redirect their investments towards renewables. Geographically, Sub-Saharan Africa received the largest flows, followed by Latin America and the Caribbean. Least-developed countries, landlocked developing countries, and small island developing states received a fairer distribution of flows compared to other developing countries. The distribution of flows by financial instrument shows a shift towards grants and equity, while the share of debt instruments has decreased. Concessional loans, grants, equity, and guarantees are important instruments for supporting clean energy projects in developing countries. However, there is a need to ensure that concessional loans do not lead to unsustainable external debt. The distribution of flows by country shows that Nigeria, Guinea, and India were the top recipients of international public financial flows in 2019. Least-developed countries, landlocked developing countries, and small island developing states received a larger share of flows compared to other developing countries. However, there is still a need to improve the distribution of flows to reach those furthest behind. Overall, there is a need for increased investments in clean energy in developing countries, especially in the least-developed countries, landlocked developing countries, and small island developing states. Donors should consider immediate changes to their investment strategies to redirect public flows from non-renewables to renewables.

The COVID-19 pandemic has slowed global progress on SDG 7, particularly in the areas of universal access to clean cooking and electricity, and energy efficiency. However, progress in renewable energy has been consistently made throughout the pandemic. New policies and commitments from governments, as well as the outcomes of COP26, have improved the outlook for achieving SDG 7. However, access setbacks caused by the pandemic have outweighed the progress in access, particularly in developing economies.

The Stated Policies Scenario and Planned Energy Scenario depict the trajectory for achieving the targets set forth in SDG 7. The Stated Policies Scenario projects that 670 million people will still lack access to electricity in 2030, with Sub-Saharan Africa being the most affected region. The COVID-19 pandemic has slowed progress on reaching universal access to electricity, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa. The outlook for access to clean cooking solutions is also concerning, with over 3 billion people projected to rely on traditional uses of biomass, kerosene, or coal for cooking in 2030. The use of renewables in the energy sector is growing, with solar PV and wind accounting for most of the growth in renewables-based electricity generation by 2030. However, current policies are insufficient to meet the goals agreed to under the Paris Agreement and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Increased investment in clean energy is needed to bridge the gap and achieve universal access to electricity and clean cooking by 2030.

The global energy transition requires the decarbonization of the electricity sector by mid-century, with a rapid increase in renewable energy generation and the electrification of heat and transport applications. This transition can be achieved through the deployment of various renewable power technologies, along with increased flexibility in the power sector. Direct uses of renewables, such as bioenergy and solar thermal, are also important in sectors like transport, buildings, and industry. The transition to clean energy requires significant investments, with an average annual investment of trillions of dollars needed to achieve the SDG targets. Improvements in energy efficiency are also crucial, with the need to double the global rate of improvement by 2030. International cooperation and support for clean energy research and technology are essential for achieving the SDG targets. The energy transition has positive socioeconomic impacts, including increased GDP, job creation, and improved welfare. Reliable and comprehensive energy data collection is crucial for tracking progress and making evidence-based decisions.

Access to electricity rates vary across countries and regions. Some countries, such as Albania, Algeria, and Argentina, have achieved near-universal access to electricity, with rates of 99-100% in both urban and rural areas. Other countries, like Afghanistan, Burkina Faso, and Chad, have much lower access rates, ranging from 11-41%. In some cases, there are significant disparities between urban and rural areas, with higher access rates in urban areas. For example, in Eswatini, the access rate is 80% overall, but only 35% in rural areas. Overall, progress has been made in increasing access to electricity globally, but there is still work to be done to ensure universal access for all.

The text provides data on the percentage of final energy consumption from renewable sources for various countries. It includes information on the share of renewable energy, such as solid biofuels, liquid biofuels, biogases, hydro, tide, wind, solar, geothermal, municipal waste, electricity consumption, heat raising, and transport.

The text provides information on various countries' energy consumption, renewable energy consumption, and installed renewable electricity-generating capacity. It also includes data on international financial flows to support clean energy in developing countries. The information is presented in a tabular format, with data for different years.

The text provides data on energy progress in different regions and countries. It mentions the regions of Southern Asia, Eastern Asia and South-eastern Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean, Western Asia and Northern Africa, Oceania excluding Australia and New Zealand, as well as specific groups such as Least Developed Countries (LDCs), Landlocked developing countries (LLDCs), and Small Island Developing States (SIDS). It also mentions the availability of data and reports on the SDG Tracking website, and acknowledges the organizations involved in producing the Energy Progress Report.

doc-61.title: Interoperability of distributed energy resources: Benefits, challenges, and solutions
doc-61.extract: Interoperability of distributed energy resources: Benefits, challenges, and solutions AT June 2023 Author Rowan Harris, Analyst, Energy Transitions Carbon Trust Advisory Ltd (Carbon Trust) Reviewed by Ross Bruton, Associate Director, Programmes, and Innovation Carbon Trust Advisory Ltd (Carbon Trust) Email: RossBruton@carbontrustcom Masaō Ashtine, Manager, Energy Transitions Carbon Trust Advisory Ltd (Carbon Trust) Email: MasaoAshtine@carbontrustcom The Carbon Trust’ mission is to accelerate the move to decarbonised future Contents Notable abbreviations Executive summary Summary insights What is interoperability and why is it important? Where and how can interoperability between DER benefit the consumer? Interface : Inverters Interface : Smart Meters 10 Interface : Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment 12 Interface : Smart Building Applications 17 Interface : Aggregators 18 Brand Interoperability 20 Interoperability Ratings, Solutions, and Policy 25 Conclusion 31 Bibliography 37 Notable abbreviations AC Alternating Current API Application Programming Interface BS British Standard BSI British Standards Institute CHAdeMO CHArge de MOve COP Code of Practice CCS Combined Charging System CSIP Common Smart
doc-61.summary:
This report discusses the benefits, challenges, and solutions related to the interoperability of distributed energy resources (DERs). DERs, such as solar PV, electric vehicles, and battery storage, play a crucial role in the energy transition and offer various benefits to consumers, including lower energy bills and access to backup power. However, limited interoperability between DER devices and the grid can hinder their full potential. Interoperability challenges range from minor inconveniences to more significant issues that prevent the realization of specific DER functions. Manufacturers are often hesitant to develop interoperable solutions due to cybersecurity concerns and added costs. Policymakers also play a role in determining the level of guaranteed interoperability. The report provides recommendations for consumers and policymakers to address interoperability issues and maximize the benefits of DERs.

Policymakers have been hesitant to standardize interoperability between devices and energy management systems, leading to a proliferation of connectivity standards and smartphone apps. However, the Matter standard, supported by companies like LG, Samsung, and Schneider Electric, shows promise in driving interoperability. Aggregators are emerging as key players in the energy market, enabling consumers to benefit from trading flexibility with the grid. Interoperability challenges include issues with access to and control of inverter-based resources, balancing individual assets on complex sites, and choosing the right internet connection for devices. The Balancing and Settlement Code modification in the UK allows for individual assets to be settled independently, ensuring proper compensation. Manufacturers should implement COP11 standards for asset meters. Compatibility between brands of DER equipment varies, with LG, BYD, and Dyness being more open to compatibility with other major inverter brands. Nissan is currently the only manufacturer offering V2G capabilities. Policymakers should focus on mandating smart inverters, ensuring internet connectivity for inverters, accelerating the implementation of standards like ISO 15118, and providing clarity on communications protocols. The Matter standard and PAS 1878 can also contribute to interoperability. Overall, addressing interoperability challenges is crucial to fully realizing the benefits of DER integration.

Decenas de familias tienen acceso a luz eléctrica tras la puesta en marcha de la Micro Hidroeléctrica Comunitaria Los Limoncitos, en La Vega, con el apoyo del Ministerio de Energía y Minas, el Programa de Pequeños Subsidios (PPS) del Programa de las Naciones Unidas para el Desarrollo, asociaciones de base comunitarias, entre otras.Además de los hogares de la zona, esta obra beneficiará a las microempresas rurales, la escuela, la iglesia y el alumbrado público de la zona. Para hacer posible el sistema micro hidroeléctrico, se contó con la participación de las personas de la comunidad, quienes estuvieron motivados tras ver el éxito de proyectos similares en otras zonas rurales del país.“Como agencia de desarrollo de la ONU, el PNUD, durante casi 3 décadas, ha hecho del empoderamiento social una de sus prioridades para acompañar la generación de soluciones locales y
doc-68.summary: The Ministry of Energy and Mines, along with other institutions, inaugurated a micro hydroelectric plant in the community of Constanza. This project, supported by the Ministry of Energy and Mines and the UNDP-PPS, provides electricity to dozens of families as well as microenterprises, schools, churches, and public lighting in the area. The project was made possible through the participation of the community, who were motivated by the success of similar projects in other rural areas of the country. The hydroelectric system utilizes water from the Los Limoncitos stream and cost approximately 25 million pesos. The project was a collaboration between various national and international institutions, and the community contributed their labor to make it possible. The operation of the micro hydroelectric plant will have positive impacts on the social, environmental, and economic aspects of the community, particularly benefiting vulnerable groups such as youth and children. The project also opens opportunities for adult literacy programs and improves the living conditions of women by reducing domestic work and allowing them to engage in other activities. Since 1997, the UNDP's Small Grants Program has implemented a global and innovative model of local solutions that provide remote communities with access to clean energy sources. Over 50 micro hydroelectric plants like this one have been put into operation, directly benefiting over 20,000 people nationwide.

doc-71.title: Energy transitions require innovation in power system planning
doc-71.extract: MID-TERM ADEQUACY REPORT on the electricity supply-demand balance in France 2019 EDITION Mid-term adequacy report on the electricity supply-demand balance in France 2019 EDITION MAIN RESULTS Mid-term adequacy report on the electricity supply-demand balance in France 2019 EDITION MAIN RESULTS EXECUTIVE SUMMARY The current level of security of supply The concept of inadequacy between electricity supply and demand has therefore remained theo- retical and unknown to the general public, unlike power cuts, which may affect some consumers following technical or clearly identifiable meteoro- logical incidents (for example, storms) Over the past 15 years, France has moved away from an overcapacity situation to, now, reach level of security of supply very close to the national reliability standard This is mainly due to the closure of oil and coal- fired facilities large number of these types of power plant (with cumulative power of almost 12 GW) have been shut down since 2012, for environmental reasons (as these facilities were amongst the highest
doc-71.summary:
The mid-term adequacy report on the electricity supply-demand balance in France for 2019 shows that the country's security of supply is currently at a level very close to the national reliability standard. This is due to the closure of oil and coal-fired power plants and the decrease in availability of the nuclear power fleet. While the security of supply is still ensured, there is no longer a capacity margin, making it increasingly important to assess the risk level of the power system. The report also highlights the challenges of implementing public energy policy while ensuring compliance with national standards. The report identifies three levers to improve security of supply: controlling demand, optimizing nuclear reactor downtimes, and maintaining or converting the Cordemais power plant. The report also discusses the transition of the power system, with a focus on the development of renewable energies and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. Overall, the report emphasizes the need to maintain the development trajectories for renewable energies and the importance of the nuclear sector in ensuring security of supply.

The French Mid-term Adequacy Report 2019 assesses the security of supply in France. It considers various factors such as the commissioning of the Flamanville EPR, the availability of reactors, the closure of coal-fired power plants, and the development of renewable energy sources. The report identifies three levers for ensuring security of supply: controlling demand, optimizing the scheduling of nuclear reactor stoppages, and maintaining the availability of the Cordemais plant. The report also highlights the importance of interconnections with neighboring countries and the potential impact of events such as prolonged cold waves or low wind periods. Overall, the report concludes that the security of supply in France is currently close to the national reliability standard, but certain periods require heightened scrutiny.

The daily load curve of electricity consumption in France shows the need for generating facilities or demand reduction measures to balance supply and demand over longer periods of time, not just during peak hours. Controlling demand is important for managing the power system and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Various initiatives, such as energy efficiency measures, specific control of power demand, and eco-gestures, can contribute to reducing peak demand. The report also discusses the optimization of nuclear reactor outages and the potential of maintaining or converting the Cordemais power plant to biomass. The growth of renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar, will lead to a decrease in the share of nuclear power in the electricity generation mix. Gas-fired power plants will play a significant role in the transition period, and the integration of electric vehicles, hydrogen production, and electric heating systems into the power system can help reduce emissions.

doc-130.extract: Electricity Market Report 2023 The IEA examines the full spectrum of energy issues including oil, gas and coal supply and demand, renewable energy technologies, electricity markets, energy efficiency, access to energy, demand side management and much more Through its work, the IEA advocates policies that will enhance the reliability, affordability and sustainability of energy in its 31 member countries, 11 association countries and beyond This publication and any map included herein are without prejudice to the status of or sovereignty over any territory, to the delimitation of international frontiers and boundaries and to the name of any territory, city or area Source: IEA International Energy Agency Website: IEA member countries: Australia Austria Belgium Canada Czech Republic Denmark Estonia Finland France Germany Greece Hungary Ireland Italy Japan Korea Lithuania Luxembourg Mexico Netherlands New Zealand Norway Poland Portugal Slovak Republic INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY Spain Sweden Switzerland Republic of Türkiye United Kingdom United States The European Commission also participates in the work of
doc-130.summary:
The IEA's Electricity Market Report 2023 provides an analysis of recent policies, trends, and market developments in the electricity sector. It predicts that global electricity demand will accelerate from 2023, led by Asia. Low-carbon sources, such as renewables and nuclear, are expected to cover almost all the growth in global electricity demand by 2025. However, the report also highlights challenges such as extreme weather events, high energy prices, and the need to increase the flexibility and security of power systems. Affordability of energy remains a challenge for emerging and developing economies, particularly in the face of surging energy commodity prices.

Asia Pacific experienced a slowdown in electricity demand growth in 2022 due to the zero-Covid policy in China, but is expected to rebound with an average growth rate of % per year between 2023 and 2025. Coal remains the dominant source of generation in the region, accounting for 57% of electricity production in 2022, but the share of low-carbon sources, including renewables and nuclear, is increasing. China is the largest electricity consumer in the region and is focusing on expanding its renewable energy capacity, with wind and solar PV expected to exceed 1250 GW by 2025. Power market reforms are also underway in China to support the transition to a modern energy system and strengthen carbon pricing mechanisms.

Electricity demand in the Americas region increased by % in 2022, with the United States accounting for the majority of the growth. However, demand is expected to decline by % in 2023 before rebounding in the following years. Renewable generation is driving down emissions in the region, with renewables accounting for 36% of annual generation in 2022. Coal-fired generation is expected to decline, while gas-fired generation will remain stable. Electricity security remains a concern in the United States, with the risk of outages during extreme weather events.

The life of Diablo Canyon Units will be extended from 2024 and 2025 to 2029 and 2030, respectively. Coal-fired generation in the United States decreased in 2022 after a sharp increase in 2021. Canada is concerned about electricity security, particularly in Alberta and the Maritimes. The expected economic slowdown in Canada in 2023 will lead to a decline in electricity demand. The refurbishment program at the Darlington and Bruce reactors in Canada will result in the temporary shutdown of five out of ten units in the second half of the year. Mexico experienced a quick recovery in energy demand following the pandemic, with electricity demand growing by almost % in 2021. The Mexican government announced a more ambitious GHG reduction target at COP27, shifting from 22% to 35% by 2030. The average CO2 intensity of Mexican power generation increased in 2022 but is expected to decline by 2025. Auctions for renewable energy projects in Mexico were halted in 2022. Brazil's electricity demand increased slightly in 2022 and is set to rise by around % per year. Hydropower generation rebounded in Brazil in 2022 after a severe drought in 2021. The CO2 intensity of power generation in Brazil is expected to continue decreasing. Chile's electricity demand grew in 2022 and is expected to continue growing in the coming years. Colombia's electricity demand fell in 2020 due to the pandemic but recovered in 2021 and 2022. Colombia's renewable capacity has helped limit fossil fuel-powered electricity. Costa Rica's electricity system is almost fully renewable. Europe's electricity consumption rebounded in 2021 but declined in 2022 due to the energy crisis triggered by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The European Union aims to reduce its dependence on Russian fossil fuels and accelerate the clean energy transition. Emergency interventions were implemented in Europe to reduce energy prices and mitigate their impact on consumers and the economy. European electricity-intensive industries decreased their production due to high electricity prices. Germany's electricity demand declined in 2022, but coal-fired power generation increased. France faced a supply imbalance due to nuclear maintenance and low hydropower generation. Italy's electricity consumption fell in 2022, and renewable output is expected to rise. Spain's electricity demand fell in 2022, but power generation increased.

The Iberian exception, also known as the "gas cap," went into effect in June 2022. It resulted in lower wholesale prices for electricity in Spain but led to increased electricity exports and a boost in gas-fired and coal-fired generation. Solar PV output increased, but there was a drop in March due to haze from the Sahara Desert. Measures have been taken to protect consumers, including reducing access charges for electricity-intensive industries. Electricity consumption in the UK declined in 2022, and there were concerns about winter power outages. The UK became a net electricity exporter for the first time in years. Electricity consumption in Turkey and Ukraine was affected by the war in Ukraine, with significant declines in demand. Electricity consumption in Eurasia and the Middle East grew, with gas-fired generation dominating the mix. In Africa, electricity consumption rebounded in 2021 and is expected to continue growing, with renewables leading the way. South Africa experienced a decline in electricity consumption due to coal availability and project delays.

The text highlights the unprecedented amount of load shedding in South Africa, with a fourfold increase in unmet demand compared to previous years. Load shedding was implemented for 205 days in 2022, and ongoing issues with new-build coal generation have resulted in more load shedding than anticipated. The outlook for the South African power sector in 2023 is potentially sombre, with new sources of generation needed to address the crisis. The text also mentions measures announced by President Cyril Ramaphosa to address the power crisis, including the removal of licensing requirements for private energy projects. The report includes data and analysis from the International Energy Agency (IEA) and acknowledges the contributions of various experts and organizations.

The figures and tables in this publication are based on data and analysis from the International Energy Agency (IEA). The IEA is responsible for the typesetting and cover design of this publication, which was completed in February 2023. Photo credits are attributed to GettyImages.

doc-138.title: Municipal building codes and the adoption of solar photovoltaics
doc-138.extract: Municipal building codes and the adoption of solar photovoltaics Stefano Carattini, Béla Figge, Alexander Gordan and Andreas Löschel October 2022 Centre for Climate Change Economics and Policy Working Paper No 405 ISSN (Online) Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment Working Paper No 380 ISSN (Online) This working paper is intended to stimulate discussion within the research community and among users of research, and its content may have been submitted for publication in academic journals It has been reviewed by at least one internal referee before publication The views expressed in this paper represent those of the authors and do not necessarily represent those of the host institutions or funders The Centre for Climate Change Economics and Policy (CCCEP) was established by the University of Leeds and the London School of Economics and Political Science in 2008 to advance public and private action on climate change through innovative, rigorous research The Centre is funded by the UK Economic
doc-138.summary:
This working paper discusses the impact of municipal building codes on the adoption of solar photovoltaics. The authors conducted a survey of municipalities in Germany to gather information on building codes related to solar installations. They found that municipalities with restrictive building codes had lower solar adoption rates. The paper highlights the trade-off between national climate goals and local preservation efforts. The authors suggest that technological advancements in solar panel aesthetics could help mitigate this trade-off.

The text discusses the impact of municipal solar policies on solar adoption in Germany. The study finds that these policies reduce the number of installations and solar capacity. The effect is larger for higher capacity solar photovoltaics. The study also examines the timing of the treatment effects and finds that they grow in magnitude over time. The results are robust to various specifications and matching strategies. Overall, the study highlights the trade-off between local and national goals in promoting renewable energy adoption.

The text discusses the administrative functions of municipalities in Germany and the distribution of municipalities by state. It also includes an email invitation sent to municipalities to participate in a survey on solar energy. The text then goes on to describe the process of building a dataset on solar installations and the definition of municipalities over time. It concludes with additional robustness tests conducted on the data.

The significance levels are as follows: * represents a significance level of less than 10%, ** represents a significance level of less than 5%, and *** represents a significance level of less than 1%.

doc-141.title: Training Solar Installers, implemented by UNDP Kosovo, aims to support training on solar panel installation at Vocational Training Centers
doc-141.extract: The solar photovoltaic industry in Kosovo has demonstrated considerable growth these past few years. Along with industry growth and the targets set on the Energy Strategy 2022-2031 the demand for solar installers is growing too, and their employment is projected to grow much faster than the average for all occupations.With the objective of enhancing and adapting the skill set of Kosovo's workforce to the evolving demands of the labor market, UNDP Kosovo organized a training on solar panel installation. The purpose of the training is for the trained individuals to transfer this acquired know-how to aspiring young professionals at the Vocational Training Center (QAP-VTC) in Kosovo, thereby equipping them with the necessary knowledge and skills for prospective employment opportunities. doc-141.summary: The solar photovoltaic industry in Kosovo has experienced significant growth in recent years. As a result, there is a growing demand for solar installers, with employment in this field projected to grow faster than average. To address this, UNDP Kosovo organized a training program on solar panel installation. The goal of the training is to equip individuals with the necessary skills to transfer their knowledge to aspiring young professionals at the Vocational Training Center in Kosovo, preparing them for employment opportunities in the industry.

doc-145.title: Transforming a Billion Lives
doc-145.extract: TRANSFORMING BILLION LIVES The job creation potential from green power transition in the energy poor world TRANSFORMING BILLION LIVES Table of Contents 02 Foreword 05 Executive Summary 09 Introduction 12 Ending energy poverty with clean & distributed energy 15 Scenario for Ending Energy Poverty by 2030 19 The Direct Job Creation Potential 23 Jobs Created through Productive Use of Energy 30 Conclusion TRANSFORMING BILLION LIVES Foreword Nearly two years into the Covid-19 pandemic, the world is experiencing great divergence Wealthier countries have spent trillions of dollars to stoke their economies, vaccinate their citizens, and adapt or transition their economies to be more digital and climate friendly, while lower-income countries—and their people—have been left behind Hundreds of millions of people in the developing world are poorer, less healthy, have fewer opportunities for education and employment, and have less access to electricity Across the world, one of the pandemic’ many side effects is job losses In matter of days, the virus transformed
doc-145.summary:
This report explores the potential for ending energy poverty through the use of distributed renewable energy technologies (DREs). It estimates that approximately 1 billion people still live in energy poverty, and investing $130 billion per year in DREs over the next decade could create 25 million new jobs in the power sector and another 500 million jobs in agriculture, healthcare, education, and small and medium-sized enterprises. The report highlights the cost-effectiveness and climate benefits of DREs compared to fossil fuels. It also emphasizes the importance of targeting vulnerable communities and advancing gender inclusion through DRE deployment. The report includes case studies on the potential for solar irrigation in Ethiopia and highlights the success of companies like SunCulture in providing affordable and efficient solar-powered irrigation systems for smallholder farmers.

Investing in distributed renewable energy (DRE) has the potential to create millions of direct and downstream jobs, particularly in developing countries. In total, around 25 million direct jobs are created, with an additional 500 million new jobs and 700 million improved jobs in downstream sectors. DRE projects create more direct jobs compared to centralized fossil fuel assets, with a job multiplier of 41 times higher. The jobs created are concentrated in sectors such as agriculture, animal production, food processing, essential services, mobility, and heavy industry. These jobs are ideal for low-skilled workers, providing opportunities for those most affected by the Covid-19 crisis. Additionally, investing in DRE can promote gender inclusion and empower women in sectors dominated by them. Specific interventions and investments are needed to support the productive use of electricity in key sectors, such as milk chilling in Nigeria and water pumping in Uganda. Overall, investing in DRE can drive economic recovery, reduce CO2 emissions, and improve the livelihoods of billions of people.

The text discusses the transformation of agricultural value chains and provides a link to the Rockefeller Foundation's initiative to improve the lives of billions of people.

doc-178.title: UNDP report shows women’s rising role in the Kazakhstan renewable energy sector
doc-178.extract: The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Kazakhstan has published an in-depth analysis of the gender balance in the renewable energy sector (RES) in Kazakhstan.The report showed that the proportion of women in Kazakhstan's energy sector remains lower than that of men. Specifically, the average representation of women in the coal industry was 22 percent, while in the oil and gas sector it was 18 percent. In contrast, the percentage of women employed in the renewable energy sector reached 30 percent, which is a positive indicator of the comparatively high attractiveness of the renewable energy sector for women compared to traditional energy sectors.Despite the positive trend, the energy sector continues to struggle with gender inequalities, especially at decision- making levels. The report revealed that in Kazakhstan, women in the energy sector are concentrated in low-skilled roles, with high percentages of unskilled women workers, especially in electricity (53 percent). Fewer women hold managerial (16 percent) or technical (19 percent) positions. In
doc-178.summary: The UNDP in Kazakhstan conducted an analysis of gender balance in the renewable energy sector. The report found that women are underrepresented in the energy sector overall, but the proportion of women in renewable energy is higher compared to traditional energy sectors. However, there are still gender inequalities, particularly in decision-making roles. The report also highlighted the global growth of the renewable energy workforce and the potential for job creation in the sector. The findings were presented at a workshop on women's empowerment in renewable energy, which aimed to address gender inequalities and establish a network of women in the sector.

doc-27.title: Behind the Blue: Community-focused solutions to harness the Blue Economy
doc-27.extract: --- Image caption ---We are faced with the indisputable fact that we are in the age of the Anthropocene – this is the first time in our history where human activity has been the dominant influence on climate and the environment. Our actions are changing the natural balance of the earth and the ocean. Acknowledging this fact, as we celebrate UN World Oceans Day, under the theme of Revitalization: Collective Action for the Ocean, we highlight the work of Caribbean Small Island Developing States (SIDS) who are at the forefront of the climate crisis. By combining resources, ideas and innovative solutions these islands are creating a brighter (bluer) future. At UNDP we stand beside our partners so as to foster a global conversation on the greatest challenges facing the oceans and seas, inspiring bold innovative thinking, new partnerships and effective action for a sustainable ocean economy.Oceans produce more than 50% of the world’s oxygen and its potential for accelerating decarbonisation
doc-27.summary: The Anthropocene is the era in which human activity has become the dominant influence on climate and the environment. Caribbean Small Island Developing States (SIDS) are at the forefront of the climate crisis and are working together to create a sustainable ocean economy. The ocean has the potential to mitigate climate change and provide economic benefits. UNDP is working with partners and communities in the Eastern Caribbean to protect and revitalize the ocean. One innovative project is BlueDIGITAL, which supports digital transformation in the blue economy and connects fishers with consumers. The influx of Sargassum Seaweed in the Caribbean is being addressed through a project funded by the Government of Japan. Collaboration and innovative thinking are essential to finding a balance between people and the planet. UNDP is committed to supporting and learning from ocean community leaders and champions in order to reposition SIDS as Big Ocean States.

doc-63.extract: The project intends to address the lack of access to energy in health facilities as well as the lack of income opportunities for women and youth. In addition, the project interventions will provide support to improving the access to health services and livelihoods overall. The overall objective of the project is to contribute to reduced energy poverty and strengthened resilience capacity of conflict affected communities through improved health services and sustainable livelihoods. The project would be implemented in Aden, Lahj, Abyan, Sana’a and Hajjah governorates, and is expected to reach approximately 205,000 individuals (106,600 men and 98,400 women).The overall objective of the project is to contribute to reduced energy poverty and strengthened resilience capacity of conflict affected communities through improved health services and sustainable livelihood.Yemen ranks last on the global gender index, and ongoing crises have disrupted traditional gender roles for both men and women. As a result, women are now permitted to engage in economic activities.The project aims to
doc-63.summary: The project aims to address the lack of energy access in health facilities and limited income opportunities for women and youth in conflict-affected communities in Yemen. It will improve access to health services and livelihoods, particularly for women and youth, through the use of solar micro-grids. The project will be implemented in five governorates and is expected to reach approximately 205,000 individuals. The objective is to reduce energy poverty and strengthen resilience capacity. The project will also promote economic empowerment for women and youth by providing employment and income opportunities. Lessons learned from the successful operation of micro-grid stations in four governorates will be applied to the scaling initiative. The project has specific outputs related to improving energy access in hospitals and providing sustained income opportunities for women and youth. The budget for the project spans from 2022 to 2024 and is funded by the United Nations Development Programme and the Kuwait Fund.

doc-164.summary:
The IEA's Electricity Market Report Update for 2023 and 2024 shows that global electricity demand growth is expected to ease in 2023 due to the ongoing global energy crisis and economic slowdowns in various regions. However, demand is forecasted to rebound in 2024. China and India are expected to see robust growth in electricity demand, while the USA and the EU are expected to experience declines. Renewable generation is set to overtake coal as the largest source of electricity by 2024, and renewables alone are expected to meet all electricity demand growth in 2023 and 2024. Emissions from power generation are poised to dip slightly through 2024, with increases in emissions in Asia offset by declines in other regions. Wholesale electricity prices remain elevated in many regions, underscoring the increased need for flexibility in the electricity market. Cooling demand is becoming an increasing challenge for power systems, and the availability of hydropower requires greater attention.

Global electricity generation from fossil fuels declined in 2020 due to the economic slowdown caused by the pandemic. However, there was a rebound in 2021, although it was short-lived. Modest growth in fossil fuel generation is expected in 2022, while declines are predicted in 2023 and 2024. Renewable generation, on the other hand, is expected to continue increasing. Coal-fired generation is increasing in China and India but declining in the US and the EU. Hydropower generation has been affected by droughts in various regions, leading to reduced capacity factors. Global CO2 emissions from power generation are expected to slightly decline through 2024. Wholesale electricity prices remain elevated in many regions, although they have declined from their peak in 2022. Negative prices have become more common in regions with a high share of variable renewable energy. Demand-side flexibility and storage can benefit from updated regulatory and market frameworks.

doc-187.extract: The combination of energy efficient technologies and green education saves energy costs and reduces CO2 emissions in housing sector.The small-town house with improved energy efficiency characteristics in Cherikov, Mogilev region.Nearly 40% of the world's CO2 emissions come from the real estate sector. Of this, around 70% are produced from operation of buildings and the remaining 30% belongs to construction. Carbon emissions from building operations and construction sectors have recently reached record high levels. Thus, enhancing the energy efficiency of buildings is critical for decarbonization of the real estate sector.Designing of behavioral strategies to promote energy efficiency among tenants in combination with the use of innovations and technological improvements can be a cost-effective way for the housing sector to reduce energy consumption and mitigate climate change.In Belarus, heating and hot water supply in residential and public buildings consumes about 35% of all heat energy produced in the country, while the total amount of greenhouse gas emissions produced by the housing sector
doc-187.summary: Energy efficient technologies and green education are being used to save energy costs and reduce CO2 emissions in the housing sector. In Belarus, efforts are being made to improve energy efficiency in small towns and rural areas through the use of innovative technologies such as smart heating systems. These initiatives have been successful in reducing energy consumption and heating costs. Additionally, educational programs are being implemented to promote green and energy-efficient behavior among residents. The goal is to cut CO2 emissions and contribute to the country's commitment to reduce emissions by 35% by 2030. The involvement of local communities, businesses, and educational institutions is crucial in addressing energy efficiency in these areas. Financial support and the development of new financing options are also important in scaling up these efforts.

doc-201.summary: The United Nations General Assembly has proposed a draft resolution to proclaim 26 January as the International Day of Clean Energy. doc-205.extract: A/69/395 United Nations General Assembly Distr.: General 22 September 2014 Original: English Sixty-ninth session Agenda items 19 (a) and (i) Sustainable development: implementation of Agenda 21, the Programme for the Further Implementation of Agenda 21 and the outcomes of the World Summit on Sustainable Development and of the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development Promotion of new and renewable sources of energy United Nations Decade of Sustainable Energy for All Report of the Secretary-General* Summary The United Nations Decade of Sustainable Energy for All (2014 -2024) offers a unique opportunity for all stakeholders to come together around a common platform to act to make sustainable energy for all a reality and, through this, help to eradicate poverty and lead to sustainable development and global prosperity. On the basis of input from Member States and other relevant stakeholders, the present report lays out some broad pillars as a global plan of action for the Decade. The report also suggests how the
doc-205.summary:
The United Nations Decade of Sustainable Energy for All (2014-2024) aims to bring stakeholders together to make sustainable energy a reality and eradicate poverty. The report suggests a global plan of action for the Decade and how to implement sustainable energy within the post-2015 development agenda. Access to modern energy services is crucial for sustainable development and the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals. However, 1.3 billion people still lack electricity and rely on solid fuels for cooking and heating. The transition to sustainable energy systems presents economic opportunities and requires action in areas such as finance, technology development, policy innovation, and governance structures. The Sustainable Energy for All initiative, launched in 2011, aims to ensure universal access to modern energy services, improve energy efficiency, and increase the share of renewable energy. The initiative has catalyzed significant commitments to sustainable energy from governments, the private sector, and civil society. Energy is recognized as central to the post-2015 development agenda, and the integration of energy goals is recommended. The World Bank estimates that $600-800 billion per year is needed to achieve sustainable energy for all, and a finance committee has been established to mobilize resources. Many countries and regions have endorsed sustainable energy for all as a political priority and made commitments to action. The report recommends that Sustainable Energy for All be used to track and monitor progress towards achieving energy commitments within the post-2015 development agenda.

The United Nations has declared 2014-2024 as the Decade of Sustainable Energy for All. The Secretary-General has appointed a Special Representative for Sustainable Energy for All to lead the coordination of activities for the Decade. The Decade aims to accelerate the transformation of global energy systems towards sustainability and to achieve universal energy access by 2030. The Global Tracking Framework will be used to measure progress during the Decade. The Decade will also support the post-2015 development agenda and contribute to the achievement of sustainable development goals. Long-term institutional structures for the Sustainable Energy for All initiative will be established in 2015.

The sustainable development goal on energy is 14-61423, which aims to achieve sustainable energy for all.
